context.p: Follow these instructions to determine the actual firing rate of the water heater:
context.note: The heaters covered by this manual are capable of modulating their firing rate. The firing rate should be checked with the heater operating at it's full firing rate.

step.cmd: Ensure there are no other gas fired appliances connected to the gas meter firing during this test.
Contact the gas supplier to determine the heating value, in Btu per cubic foot, of the gas supply.
Start the water heater and ensure it is firing.
Locate the gas meter serving the water heater.
Using a stop watch, time how long (in seconds) it takes for one cubic foot of gas to be used while the water heater is firing.
Use the formula below to “clock” the gas meter and determine the actual firing rate of the water heater based on the heating value (Btu per cubic foot) of the gas supply:

ul.li: T = time, in seconds, to burn one cubic foot of gas.
H = heating value of gas in Btu per cubic foot.
Btu/hr = actual firing rate of the water heater.

info.note: 1050 Btu per cubic foot is a standard value for natural gas. Standard propane gas Btu content is 2500 Btu per cubic foot. Btu values may change in certain areas and at high elevations. Check with the local gas utility company.
